A **voulge** is a type of [weapon](/wiki/Weapon "Weapon") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. It is a [two-handed](/wiki/Two-handed "Two-handed") [polearm](/wiki/Polearm "Polearm") that is made of [iron](/wiki/Iron "Iron"), and appears as a **pole cleaver** when [unidentified](/wiki/Identification "Identification").

## Generation

In addition to random generation, general [shops](/wiki/Shop "Shop") and antique weapons outlets can sell voulges.

[Watchmen](/wiki/Watchmen "Watchmen") and [soldiers](/wiki/Soldier "Soldier") may [be generated with](/wiki/Monster_starting_inventory "Monster starting inventory") a voulge.[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)

## Strategy

The voulge is the second-heaviest polearm after both the [halberd](/wiki/Halberd "Halberd") and [lucern hammer](/wiki/Lucern_hammer "Lucern hammer"), but has relatively high damage against [small](/wiki/Small "Small") monsters mixed with low average damage against large monsters - it is still quite unlikely to see much use, as the [ranseur](/wiki/Ranseur "Ranseur") deals the same damage with 2⁄5 of the [weight](/wiki/Weight "Weight").

## History

The voulge is introduced with all other polearms in [NetHack 1.3d](/wiki/NetHack_1.3d "NetHack 1.3d").

## Origin

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Voulge](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Special:Search/Voulge "wikipedia:Special:Search/Voulge")***

[![Voulges-Colored.png](/images/thumb/9/9b/Voulges-Colored.png/300px-Voulges-Colored.png)](/wiki/File:Voulges-Colored.png)



A voulge, also spelled vouge and sometimes called a couteau de breche, is a type of polearm that existed in medieval Europe, primarily in 15th century France. A voulge usually had a narrow single-edged blade mounted on a shaft via socket, and might additionally feature shaft reinforcements protection for the hands at the blade's base. The voulge has a somewhat broader blade compared to that of a [glaive](/wiki/Glaive "Glaive"), and features a shorter blade and longer shaft compared to the [bardiche](/wiki/Bardiche "Bardiche"). Troops that used the weapon are called voulgiers, with the most notable ones being the Francs-Archers ("free archers"): they were the first attempt at the formation of regular infantry in France, and voulges are depicted in the artwork of their establishment.

In modern times, the voulge is erroneously defined as a pointy cleaver-like weapon blade attached to the shaft with two hoops akin to a bardiche - this incorrect definition started in the 19th century with Viollet le Duc, and the weapon in question is an early form of [halberd](/wiki/Halberd "Halberd").

## Variants

### dNetHack

In [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack") and [notdNetHack](/wiki/NotdNetHack "NotdNetHack"), the voulge has its weight reduced to 50 aum, the same as the ranseur.

[Peasants](/wiki/Peasant "Peasant") may be generated with voulges.

### NetHack Fourk

[NetHack Fourk](/wiki/NetHack_Fourk "NetHack Fourk") removes the voulge and many other polearms.

### xNetHack

[xNetHack](/wiki/XNetHack "XNetHack") removes the voulge and many other polearms.

### EvilHack

In [EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack"), [gnolls](/wiki/Gnoll_\(EvilHack\) "Gnoll (EvilHack)"), [gnoll hunters](/wiki/Gnoll_hunter "Gnoll hunter") and [flinds](/wiki/Flind_\(EvilHack\) "Flind (EvilHack)") have an effective 1⁄12 chance of generating with a voulge as their weapon.

A voulge can be created at a [forge](/wiki/Forge_\(dungeon_feature\) "Forge (dungeon feature)") by combining a [axe](/wiki/Axe "Axe") and a [spear](/wiki/Spear "Spear").

### Hack'EM

In [Hack'EM](/wiki/Hack%27EM "Hack'EM"), [gnolls](/wiki/Gnoll_\(SLASH%27EM\) "Gnoll (SLASH'EM)") have the same odds of generating with a voulge as in EvilHack, as do flinds. Forging recipes are the same as in EvilHack.

## Encyclopedia entry

- *See the [encyclopedia entry for polearm](/wiki/Polearm#Encyclopedia_entry "Polearm").*
